options.B: for toxins and ions to be actively secreted

options.A: Sodium is pumped into the blood while potassium is actively transported out of the
options.B: A higher sodium concentration is produced in the renal medulla that osmotically draws
options.C: Glucose and sodium are cotransported from urine back into blood.

text: The ability to form concentrated urine depends on the functions of the

options.E: nephron loop, distal convoluted tubule and the collecting duct.

text: The mechanism for producing a concentrated urine involves all of the following except

options.A: the secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) by the posterior pituitary gland.
options.B: aquaporins being inserted into the membranes of the collecting duct cells.
options.C: a high concentration of N a C l in the interstitial fluid that surrounds the collecting ducts.
options.D: an increase in facultative water reabsorption.
options.E: water reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule.

text: A patient consistently produces a large volume of dilute urine. This may be due to
Antidiuretic hormone

options.A: increases the permeability of the collecting ducts to water.
options.B: is secreted in response to low potassium ion in the blood.
options.C: causes the kidneys to produce a larger volume of very dilute urine.
options.D: is secreted by the anterior pituitary.
options.E: release is insensitive to the osmolarity of interstitial fluid.

text: If a urine sample is dark yellow in color, which of the following will be true?

options.A: It will have a low pH.
options.B: It will have the odor of ammonia.
options.C: It will contain large amounts of urobilin.
options.D: It will contain excess chloride ion.
options.E: It will have a high pH.

text: When the level of ADH (antidiuretic hormone) decreases,

options.C: the osmolarity of the urine decreases.
options.D: permeability to water in the collecting system increases.
options.E: water reabsorption increases in the nephron loop.

text: As the filtrate passes through the renal tubules, approximately what percentage is
In response to increased levels of aldosterone, the kidneys produce

options.B: urine with a higher concentration of sodium ions.
options.C: urine with a lower concentration of potassium ions.
options.D: urine with a lower concentration of sodium ions.

text: Which of the following is a not a true statement regarding the countercurrent multiplication

options.A: The thin limb of the nephron loop is permeable to water.
options.B: The thick limb of the nephron loop is permeable to solutes.
options.C: The osmotic concentration of the fluid in the nephron loop decreases in the thin limb.
options.D: Tubule fluid arrives at the DCT at about 100 mOsm/L.
options.E: The maximum solute concentration is about 1200 mOsm/L.

text: Excess release of natriuretic peptides would cause

options.A: a large volume of concentrated urine.
options.B: a large volume of dilute urine.
options.C: a small volume of concentrated urine.
options.D: a small volume of dilute urine.

text: The final composition of urine is represented by which of the following statements?

options.B: Urine = substances filtered + substances reabsorbed + substances secreted.
options.C: Urine = substances secreted – substances reabsorbed – substances filtered.
options.D: Urine = substances filtered – substances reabsorbed + substances secreted.
options.E: Urine = substances reabsorbed – substances secreted – substances filtered.

text: How would the absence of an osmolarity gradient in the renal medulla affect the volume

options.E: It would have no effect on either urine volume or concentration.

text: Which of the following locations would you expect to utilize the most ATP?

options.B: thin descending limb of the nephron loop
options.C: thick ascending limb of the nephron loop

text: Facultative water reabsorption occurs in which portion of the nephron?

options.C: thin descending limb of the nephron loop
options.D: thick ascending limb of the nephron loop

text: The ureters and urinary bladder are lined by ________ epithelium.
The detrusor muscle

options.A: moves urine along the ureters by peristalsis.
options.B: compresses the urinary bladder expelling urine.
options.D: functions as the external urethral sphincter.

text: Which of the following describes when the kidneys are unable to maintain homeostasis?

Insoluble deposits that form within the urinary tract from calcium salts, magnesium salts, or

The pontine storage center controls micturition by

options.B: increasing contraction of the detrusor muscle and the internal urethral sphincter.
options.C: relaxing the internal urethral sphincter and increasing detrusor muscle activity.
options.D: increasing contraction of the external urethral sphincter and reducing detrusor muscle

text: Which of the following statements is false regarding micturition?

options.A: When you relax the external urethral sphincter, the internal sphincter will relax.
options.B: Urination can occur despite voluntary opposition.
options.C: Parasympathetic control is involved with the micturition reflex.
options.D: The micturition reflex requires the vagus nerve.
options.E: Bladder contractions can force open the internal urethral sphincter.

text: Changes that occur in the urinary system with aging include all of the following except

options.A: a decline in the number of functional nephrons.
options.B: a reduction in the GFR (glomerular filtration rate).
options.D: less control of the micturition reflex.
